primary_factors: No snowfall/accumulation expected during the decision and bus window (forecast snow = 0")
Temperatures/wind chills are cold but nowhere near Michigan extreme-cold closure thresholds (no credible ≤ -20°F wind chill signal)
Primary hazard is localized refreeze/black ice + mist/fog (05:00–09:00) rather than widespread impassable roads
Infrastructure posture is normal; roads are currently clear and only spot salting is likely needed (bridges, shaded/rural connectors, school lots)
News/community signals: no confirmed neighboring-district closures/delays and no active closings on local TV closing lists at time checked; no buzz
decision_rationale: All experts largely agree this is not a classic Michigan closure setup: no snow, no freezing rain signal, light winds, and no extreme wind chill (web verifier found no ≤ -20°F bus-hour wind chills; Weather.com is warmer than the API but both are above closure thresholds). The only meaningful operational risk is a narrow 5–9 AM window of patchy black ice from residual moisture/refreeze plus mist/low clouds—typically a *delay* or “open but cautious” scenario, not a full closure, especially with Kent County’s normal treatment capacity and clear state/county roads. News intelligence also shows no confirmed domino-effect closures yet (FOX 17 closings page showed none active at check time). Power-outage risk is low given very low systemwide outages (127 customers) and no wind/ice load risk overnight. Net: closure is possible only if a surprise glaze develops broadly across secondary roads and multiple early-morning slide-offs occur; otherwise schools should operate normally with enhanced spot-treatment and caution messaging.

collaboration.summary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 3.0% spread. Average probability: 5%.
